The resolution we are marking up today moves us closer to sufficiently curbing methane emissions. But our work cannot stop here. We must work together to form an ambitious and durable long-term framework.

Third, our companies can lead the world in developing tech. to monitor and reduce methane emissions. Small businesses comprise two-thirds of the methane mitigation industry and represent the best of US innovation, creating economic opportunity and tackling global challenges.

Second, reducing methane emissions is critical to the economic competitiveness of the U.S. natural gas industry. World markets and domestic politics won't tolerate natural gas as a ‚Äúbridge fuel‚Äù unless the industry can credibly prove that it has fixed its methane challenge.

First, controlling methane is the single most important step we can take to combat the #ClimateCrisis. ‚úîÔ∏é empowering local decision-making, and

Voluntary associations, which often comprise local chapters within a larger organization, have been losing ground to national, professionally run organizations. Formal membership in many associations fell from 75% to 62% from 1974 to 2004, the most recent year of available data.

Any portrait of American civil society would be incomplete without a diversity of voluntary associations. These local groups can have wildly different functions, ranging from Rotary Club to Little League to the Knights of Columbus. All provide tangible benefits.
